title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 11
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: We can leave these Hielandmen behind us on the rock, andone of your boats from the Castleton can bring them off to-morrow.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 11
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: We had a grand take, Imind, and the way that the fish lay broucht us near in by the Bass,whaur we forgathered wi' anither boat that belanged to a man SandieFletcher in Castleton.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 11
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Attimes a boat came from the Castleton and brought us a quarter of mutton,for the sheep upon the rock we must not touch, these being specially fedto market.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: The drive fromCastleton to Balmoral, particularly the beautifulfr.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: When we reached Castleton the day had cleared,and we were able to open the carriage again.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: The next stage of 1 5 miles to Castletonis over a very bad, and at night, positively dangerous road, through wild, grand scenery, withvery abrupt turns and steep ascents.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We got downto the road to the Spittal Bridge, about 1 5 milesfrom Castleton, at nearly half-past four, and thendown along the new road, at least that part ofit which is finished, and which is to extend tothe Cairn Wall.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We took post-horses at Castleton,and proceeded up Glen Clunie to Glen Callater,Cft  st]

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: Near Castleton, and indeed all along the road,in the shade, the frost still lay, and the air wasvery sharp.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: Changed horses atCastleton, and drove beyond the Linn of Dee tothe Giuly or Geldie Water — just where lastyear we mounted our ponies, 18 miles from Balmoral.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: Down came a heavy shower ; but before we reachedCastleton it cleared; blue sky appeared; and, asthere was much wind, Grant thought all would bewell, and the day very fine.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We three ladies drove in thesociable : Albert and Louis in a carriage fromCastleton.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: Wetook our own horses at Castleton, and reachedBalmoral at ten minutes past eight, much pleasedwith the success of our expedition, and really nottired.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We took post-horses at Castleton, anddrove up to the Derry (the road up Glen Luievery bad indeed) ; and here we mounted ourponies, and proceeded the usual way up GlenDerry, as far as where the path turns up to LochEtchan.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: Breakfastedat Balmoral in our own room at half-past seveno'clock, and started at eight or a little past, withLady Churchill and General Grey, in the sociable(Grant and Brown on the box as usual) for Castleton,where we changed horses.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We reachedCastleton at half-past seven — and after this itbecame cloudy.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: At Castleton we took four post-horses, and drove to theShiel of the Derry, that beautiful spot where wewere last year — which Albert had never seen —and arrived there just before eleven.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: The forest was anciently named De Alio Pccco, and includedthe parishes of Castleton, Hope, Chapel, orBoden and Glossop, in Derbyshire, andMotram in Chester.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Mam Toe, a considerable mountain ofEngland, in Derbyshire, containing leadmines in the peak near Castleton.

title: David Balfour, etc.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: We can leavethese Hielandmen behind us on the rock, and one ofyour boats from the Castleton can bring them off tomorrow.

title: David Balfour, etc.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: We had a grand take, I mind, aud theway that the fish lay broucht us near in by the Bass,whaur we forgaithered wi' anither boat that belangedto a man Sandie Fletcher in Castleton.

title: David Balfour, etc.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: At times aboat came from the Castleton and brought us a quarterof mutton, for the sheep upon the rock we must nottouch, these being specially fed to market.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: On the 6th September, 1715, the noblemen, chiefs of clans, gentlemen, and others,with such followers as they could immediately get in readiness, assembled atAboyne; and the Earl of Mar, acting as General on the occasion, displayed theroyal standard, at Castleton, in Braemar; and proclaimed, with such solemnity asthe time and place admitted, James King of Scotland, by the title of James VIII.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: It isin the parish of Castleton.
